ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 2 hour
8-10 on average. More than that for some assignments.
5 hours
5 hours
4 hours
12 hours per week on average, but it varied a lot from week to week.

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: only 4 homework assignments, one final project idea presentation (5 mins), and a final project
The nonparametric course was both interesting and engaging. The material was interesting and Professor Zhang did a great job of presenting and explaining it.
The course topics are useful and cutting edge. It involves methods widely used in different areas. But I prefer the instructor to give more details of methods discussed in the course.

The content covers the majority of modern nonparametric techniques, and the designated textbooks are great resources. However, I don't think the course fulfills its goal, if it has a clearly-defined goal at all. It seems to me that, instead of finding a good balance between theoretical and practical aspects of the methods, it wildly oscillated between the two extremes. I don't think students coming out of the course would have the deep theoretical understanding that the lectures and homework sometimes tried aiming at. Nor would they have enough confidence to comfortably put those methods into use, because there was almost no training provided by this course in that aspect. In general, I am pretty disappointed by this course, and I benefited from it a lot less from other statistics classes I have taken at Yale.
The lectures were very helpful and it is useful to have the lecture slides before hand. There are several very interesting and useful topics covered in this class.
Very helpful, especially the project.

This course talks about nonparametric identification like kernel, splines, tree-based methods. It is a very useful course and we can apply directly what we learn into our research. Although this course covers the asymptotic property of kernel regression, the pace of this course is too slow and we only introduce some topics and idea. This course is more like machine learning rather than nonparametric identification. I expect this course to be a very rigorous class about nonparametric identification including minimax rate, but unfortunately the course does not cover this broad and rich topic. In addition, the weekly meeting (1 hour and 50 minutes) is not very efficient and productive because every week we only cover small amount of topic. I highly suggest that we could meet twice a week for 1 hour 20 minutes like the class in Statistics Department where class usually meets twice a week. I like the topic of tree-based methods but I think it is redundant and too slow. We spent almost half the semester in tree-based method but it is possible to talk about regression and classification tree in one class.
More organized.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Heping Zhang  very patient, explain students' questions with clear details
Instructor: Heping Zhang  Professor Zhang is extremely knowledgeable and is able to clearly communicate the concepts learned in class.
Instructor: Heping Zhang  He gives clear lecture and he is very nice and passionate.

Instructor: Heping Zhang  The instructor is clearly an expert in this field, with a lot of experience and knowledge. However, I don't think the course fulfills its goal, if it has a clearly-defined goal at all. It seems to me that, instead of finding a good balance between theoretical and practical aspects of the methods, it wildly oscillated between the two extremes. I don't think students coming out of the course would have the deep theoretical understanding that the lectures and homework sometimes tried aiming at. Nor would they have enough confidence to comfortably put those methods into use, because there was almost no training provided by this course in that aspect. In general, I am pretty disappointed by this course, and I benefited from it a lot less from other statistics classes I have taken at Yale. I particularly find the homework assignments of this course of very little help. Also, the instructor picked course materials from many different textbooks, which is fine. However, he did not provide clear information on which parts of those book best correspond with his lectures, which made self-study very difficult.
Instructor: Heping Zhang  The instructor was excellent in explaining methods and ideas!
Instructor: Heping Zhang  Prof. Zhang's lectures were very clear and having lecture notes beforehand was helpful in focusing on listening to the professor rather than writing down things.
Instructor: Heping Zhang  Excellent instructor. Very good to students.
Instructor: Heping Zhang  Good teacher

Instructor: Heping Zhang  The professor is very knowledgeable and good at explaining. He cares about his students and supervises us to choose a good research topic for our term paper. He is patient about our questions. He will write notations in blackboard for us to understand better about the material.
Instructor: Heping Zhang  Good at explain things in a very intuitive way.

Instructor: Heping Zhang  Professor Zhang explains concepts very clearly. I think his explanations are intuitive, and he's great at pointing out what is most important in each lecture. I also liked that he emphasized being an active, critical thinker and understanding the reasoning behind each method, instead of focusing on details in the math. The lectures are engaging, too, because Professor Zhang is very funny. Overall, I really enjoyed the lectures in this course.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: this course is for those who have been already familiar with a majority of parametric methods, and for those who have research topic that is correlated/involved with nonparametric methodologies
This course is very helpful. However, if you want to grasp the knowledge of the course thoroughly, you need to do your own homework besides the assigned load.

There is probably no good alternatives offered by Yale on a relatively practical nonparametric statistics class (the one by the stats department is way too theoretical for someone what just want to learn new ways to analyze his/her data), but it is not a good course itself. I would be cautious in recommending it to another student, for the reasons I listed above in Questions 6-7.
Definitely recommended if you are interested in the topic!
Good course. Recommended to other students interested in statistics or data science.
Very useful course.
This course goes through non parametric methods. It is a very challenging course but you will learn a lot.
The course is very intuitive. Maybe we can have more homework with application focus not theoretical focus.
